The Nasdaq composite index declined 25.80, or 1.68 percent, to 1,510.89, and the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index fell 3.97 points to 984.59.

Nasdaq and S.& P. Decline, While Dow Climbs Slightly Stocks were mixed in a volatile session as investors remained nervous about the world economy and the prospects for improvement. The Nasdaq composite index declined 25.80, or 1.68 percent, to 1,510.89, and the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index fell 3.97 points to 984.59.

The Dow Jones industrial average ended 16.74 points higher at 7,742.98, helped by better-than-expected earnings at Alcoa and Motorola. But many investors used brief rallies during the day as an opportunity to sell. [Page C10.]

Allied Signal Gains in AMP Takeover Pennsylvania's House of Representatives approved legislation that would aid Allied Signal's $9.8 billion hostile bid for AMP by allowing AMP shareholders to hold a special meeting to consider the deal. [C5.]
AT&T's New Lucky Dog Phone Unit AT&T has introduced the Lucky Dog Phone service, the first product in the telecommunication company's 113-year history that does not use the AT&T name. [A1.]
A Challenge From Europe European governments are challenging the United States over how to address the world financial crisis, suggesting that new ideas and leadership are needed. [A1.]
The president of the World Bank publicly broke with the crisis strategy adopted by the United States and the I.M.F. [A6.]

Brazilian Market Increases 3.49% Brazilian investors took the decision by Spain's central bank to cut interest rates by half a percentage point as a sign that Europe would begin taking steps to alleviate the crisis threatening Brazil. This spurred the Brazilian market, the Bovespa, to jump 3.49 percent, or 213.51 points, to 6,336.35. [C3.]
Russian Leader Appeals for Calm Russia's Prime Minister appealed for calm as Communists and trade unionists prepared to strike over the ravaged economy. [A3.]

I.B.M. in Deal With France Telecom France Telecom and I.B.M. plan to develop a network to let customers surf the Internet with screen-based telephones. If all goes according to plan, the new devices would give technophobic customers access to the Internet without using a personal computer. [C2.]

China Investment Company Closed China shut the investment company of its richest province because it was unable to pay debts, a sign of the nation's growing financial strains. Guangdong International Trust and Investment Corporation's license was revoked, state-run media reported. [C2.]

Opposition Gains to Japan Proposal A plan by the Japanese Government to shift debt of 180 billion yen, or $1.34 billion, onto seven railway companies formed when the national railroad system was privatized is receiving opposition. [C2.]

Philippine Airlines Will Fly Again The death of Philippine Airlines was premature. The country's President, Joseph Estrada, has settled a strike by its union and its debt. A number of the carrier's domestic flights will be reinstated this week, and there is talk of resuming flights to the United States next week. Business Travel. [C6.]

Can Cabbage Patch Doll Be Beat? Tiger Electronics has started a television campaign for this sweet, if slightly scary-looking, little playmate called Furby, which the company hopes will be a big seller this holiday season. Furby, which is described as having bug eyes, big ears and a playful voice that becomes snippy if not enough attention is paid to the creature, sells for about $30. Advertising. [C8.]
